tit.e: The Narrow Road to the Deep North (Oku no Hosomichi)
The Narrow Road to the Deep North (Oku no Hosomichi)
Oku no Hosomichi (The Narrow Road to the Deep North)
tit.cmt: 説明と読みを入れ替えました。

sen.j: 奥の細道（おくのほそみち）とは、松尾芭蕉が元禄に著した紀行本。
sen.e: The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a travelogue written by Basho MATSUO in the Genroku era.
The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a travelogue written by Basho MATSUO in the Genroku era.
The Narrow Road to the Deep North is a travelogue written by Basho MATSUO in the Genroku era.
It was published in 1702.
It was published in 1702.
It was published in 1702.

sen.j: 日本の古典における紀行作品の代表的存在であり、松尾芭蕉の著書の中でも最も有名な作品である。
sen.e: It is the leading travelogue among Japanese classic and was also the best known work among the books written by Basho MATSUO.
It is the leading travelogue among Japanese classics and was also the best known work among the books written by Basho MATSUO.
It is the leading travelogue among Japanese classics and was also the best known work among the books written by Basho MATSUO.

sen.j: また、原文の題名は「おくのほそ道」であり、中学校国語の検定済み教科書ではすべてその表記法をとっている。
sen.e: The original title 'Oku no Hosomichi' was written mostly in hiragana except for 'michi' at the end which was written in kanji and the authorized textbook used for Language Arts in the middle school in Japan conforms to that notational convention.

The original title 'Oku no Hosomichi' was written mostly in hiragana except for 'michi' at the end which was written in kanji and the authorized textbook used for Language Arts in the middle school in Japan conforms to that notational convention.

The original title 'Oku no Hosomichi' was written mostly in hiragana except for 'michi' at the end which was written in kanji and the authorized textbook used for Language Arts in the middle school in Japan conforms to that notational convention.
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 作品中には多数の俳句が読み込まれている。
sen.e: Numerous haiku poems are included in this book.
Numerous haiku poems are included in this book.
Numerous haiku poems are included in this book.

sen.j: 読み易い版として岩波書店文庫、角川書店文庫ソフィア、講談社学術文庫がある。
sen.e: The easy-to-read editions have been published by Iwanami Shoten Bunko, the Sophia Library of Kadokawa Group Publishing Co., Ltd. and the Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.
The easy-to-read editions have been published by Iwanami Shoten Bunko, the Sophia Library of Kadokawa Group Publishing Co., Ltd. and the Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.
The easy-to-read editions have been published by Iwanami Shoten Bunko, the Sophia Library of Kadokawa Group Publishing Co., Ltd. and the Academic paperback library, Kodansha Ltd.

sen.j: 芭蕉が弟子の河合曾良を伴って、元禄2年3月27日 (旧暦)（新暦1689年5月16日）に江戸深川 (江東区)の採荼庵を出発した（行く春や鳥啼魚の目は泪）。
sen.e: On May 16, 1689, Basho and his pupil Sora KAWAK left Saitoan (Basho's hermitage) in Fukagawa, Edo (presently Koto Ward) to begin the journey to north and on his departure, Basho composed the poem reading, 'The spring is passing – the birds all mourn and fishes' eyes are wet with tears.'
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処 出典：http://www.tclt.org.uk/basho/Basho_Oku_no_Hosomichi.pdf
sen.e: On May 16, 1689, Basho and his pupil Sora KAWAK left Saitoan (Basho's hermitage) in Fukagawa, Edo (presently Koto Ward) to begin the journey to north and on his departure, Basho composed the poem reading, 'The spring is passing – the birds all mourn and fishes' eyes are wet with tears.'

On May 16, 1689, Basho and his pupil Sora KAWAI left Saitoan (Basho's hermitage) in Fukagawa, Edo (presently Koto Ward) to begin the journey to north and on his departure, Basho composed the poem reading, 'The spring is passing – the birds all mourn and fishes' eyes are wet with tears.'
sen.cmt: KAWAI訂正しました。全角の’’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 全行程約600里（2400キロメートル）、日数約150日間（約半年）中に東北・北陸を巡って元禄4年（1691年）に江戸に帰った。
sen.e: It took approximately 150 days, with the total distance covered being approximately 2400 kilometers traveling the Tohoku and Hokuriku districts and Basho returned to Edo in 1691.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: It took approximately 150 days, with the total distance covered being approximately 2400 kilometers traveling the Tohoku and Hokuriku districts and Basho returned to Edo in 1691.
It took approximately 150 days, with the total distance covered being approximately 2400 kilometers traveling the Tohoku and Hokuriku districts and Basho returned to Edo in 1691.

sen.j: 奥の細道では、旧暦8月21日頃大垣に到着するまでが書かれている（蛤のふたみにわかれ行秋ぞ）。
sen.e: Oku no Hosomichi chronicled Basho's journey up to his arrival in Ogaki around October 4, 1689 (when he composed the haiku that says, 'Like a clam ripped from its shell, autumn is deepening now.'
Oku no Hosomichi chronicled Basho's journey up to his arrival in Ogaki around October 4, 1689 (when he composed the haiku that says, 'Like a clam ripped from its shell, autumn is deepening now.'
Oku no Hosomichi chronicled Basho's journey up to his arrival in Ogaki around October 4, 1689 (when he composed the haiku that says, 'Like a clam ripped from its shell, autumn is deepening now.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 月日は百代の過客にして…という序文により始まる。
sen.e: It begins with the preface which goes, 'The days and months are travelers of eternity ………….'
It begins with the preface which goes, 'The days and months are travelers of eternity ………….'
It begins with the preface which goes, ''The days and months are travelers of eternity ….'
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。不要な･･･削除しました。

Itinerary
Itinerary

sen.j: 元禄2年春 芭蕉は旅立ちの準備をすすめ、隅田川のほとりにあった芭蕉庵を引き払う。
sen.e: In the spring of 1689, in preparation to begin his journey, Basho vacated the Bashoan (the hut, in which Basho lived) near Sumida-gawa River.
In the spring of 1689, in preparation to begin his journey, Basho vacated the Bashoan (the hut, in which Basho lived) near Sumida-gawa River.
In the spring of 1689, in preparation to begin his journey, Basho vacated the Bashoan (the hut, in which Basho lived) near Sumida-gawa River.

sen.j: 草の戸も 住み替はる代（よ）ぞ 雛の家
sen.e: Even this grass hut could for the new owner be a festive house of dolls
Even this grass hut could for the new owner be a festive house of dolls
Even this grass hut could for the new owner be a festive house of dolls

sen.j: 3月27日 明け方、採荼庵（さいとあん）より舟に乗って出立する。
sen.e: At dawn of May 16, 1689, Basho and KAWAI left by a boat from Saitoan (Basho's hermitage).

sen.e: At dawn of May 16, 1689, Basho and KAWAI left by a boat from Saitoan (Basho's hermitage).

sen.j: 千住で船を下りて詠む。
sen.e: They got off the boat at Senju and Basho composed the following haiku.

sen.j: 行く春や 鳥啼（なき）魚の目は泪
sen.e: The spring is passing – the birds all mourn and fishes' eyes are wet with tears

sen.e: May 19, 1689, composed in Nikko City, Tochigi Prefecture

sen.j: あらたふと 青葉若葉の 日の光
sen.e: How holy a place green leaves, young leaves, and through them the sunlight now bursts

tit.j: 黒羽 雲巌寺 光明寺
tit.cmt: 不要なハイフンをコンマに訂正しました。スペース削除しました。

sen.j: 4月4日 栃木県大田原市黒羽を訪れ、黒羽藩城代家老浄法寺高勝、俳号桃雪の元に投宿。
sen.e: May 22, 1689, Basho visited Kurobane, Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture and stayed with the Jodaigaro (chief counselor of a castle) of the Kurobane Clan Takakatsu JOHOJI whose haigo (the pen name of a haiku poet) was Tosetsu.

May 22, 1689, Basho visited Kurobane, Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture and stayed with the Jodaigaro (chief counselor of a castle) of the Kurobane Clan Takakatsu JOHOJI whose haigo (the pen name of a haiku poet) was Tosetsu.

sen.j: 4月5日 栃木県大田原市の雲巌寺に禅の師匠であった住職・仏頂和尚を訪ねる。
sen.e: May 23, 1689, Bacho visited his former zen instructor Buccho-osho, the resident priest of Ungen-ji Temple in Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture.
May 23, 1689, Bacho visited his former zen instructor Buccho-osho, the resident priest of Ungen-ji Temple in Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture.

sen.j: 木啄も庵はやぶらず夏木立
sen.e: Even woodpeckers leave the hermitage untouched in the summer trees
Even woodpeckers leave the hermitage untouched in the summer trees
Even woodpeckers leave the hermitage untouched in the summer trees

sen.j: 4月9日 栃木県大田原市の修験光明寺に招かれて行者堂を拝する。
sen.e: May 27, 1689, Basho was invited to Shugenkomyo-ji Temple in Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture where Basho viewed the training hall for practitioners.
May 27, 1689, Basho was invited to Shugenkomyo-ji Temple in Otawara City, Tochigi Prefecture where Basho viewed the training hall for practitioners.

sen.j: 夏山に足駄を拝む首途哉
sen.e: In summer mountains we say prayers before the shoes --- journey now begins
In summer mountains we say prayers before the shoes --- journey now begins

tit.j: 那須 温泉神社 殺生石

sen.j: 4月19日 栃木県那須町の温泉神社に那須与一を偲び、殺生石を訪ねる。
sen.e: June 6, 1689, to commemorate NASU no Yoichi, visited Sesshoseki (the murder stone) at Onsen-jinja Shrine (a shrine to the god of hot spring) in Nasu City, Tochigi Prefecture.

sen.j: 野を横に馬牽むけよほととぎす

Turn the horse's head towards the plain; pull there now! A cuckoo's calling

sen.j: 4月20日 福島県白河市
sen.e: June 7, 1689, wrote in Shirakawa City, Fukushima Prefecture
June 7, 1689, wrote in Shirakawa City, Fukushima Prefecture
June 7, 1689, wrote in Shirakawa City, Fukushima Prefecture

sen.j: 「心許なき日かず重るまゝに、白川の関にかゝりて旅心定りぬ」
sen.e: Day after day had passed in vague uneasiness, but now we approached the Barrier at Shirakawa, and, for the first time, I felt that our journey had truly begun.'
Day after day had passed in vague uneasiness, but now we approached the Barrier at Shirakawa, and, for the first time, I felt that our journey had truly begun.'

sen.j: 5月4日 壺の碑（多賀城碑）を見て「行脚の一徳、存命の悦び、
sen.e: May 20, 1689, it was said that, at the sight of Tsubo no ishibumi (stone monument) (or Tagajo hi, an old stone in Tagajo-City, Miyagi Prefecture), shedding tears, Basho said, 'This is the travelers' reward, the joy of having lived so long.

May 20, 1689, it was said that, at the sight of Tsubo no ishibumi (stone monument) (or Tagajo hi, an old stone in Tagajo-City, Miyagi Prefecture), shedding tears, Basho said, 'This is the travelers' reward, the joy of having lived so long.

sen.j: 羇旅の労をわすれて泪も落るばかり也」と涙をこぼしたという。
sen.e: I forget the hardships of the road and am moved to tears.'
I forget the hardships of the road and am moved to tears.'
I forget the hardships of the road and am moved to tears.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 5月9日 歌枕松島（宮城県宮城郡松島町）芭蕉は「いづれの人か筆をふるひ詞（ことば）を尽くさむ」とここでは句を残さなかった。
sen.e: June 25, 1689, at Utamakura (place names used in Japanese poetry, where a kind of code with a special meaning, mood, season or other reference to history is implied) Matsushima (Matsushima Town, Miyagi County, Miyagi Prefecture), Basho did not compose a haiku saying, 'What painter or writer could ever capture fully the wonder of the masterpiece of nature?'

June 25, 1689, at Utamakura (place names used in Japanese poetry, where a kind of code with a special meaning, mood, season or other reference to history is implied) Matsushima (Matsushima Town, Miyagi County, Miyagi Prefecture), Basho did not compose a haiku saying, 'What painter or writer could ever capture fully the wonder of the masterpiece of nature?'

June 25, 1689, at Utamakura (place names used in Japanese poetry, where a kind of code with a special meaning, mood, season or other reference to history is implied) Matsushima (Matsushima Town, Miyagi County, Miyagi Prefecture), Basho did not compose a haiku saying, 'What painter or writer could ever capture fully the wonder of the masterpiece of nature?'
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 「松島や ああ松島や 松島や」と詠んだといわれるのは後の人々が考え出した作り話である。
sen.e: The legend that Basho composed the haiku that reads, 'Oh Matsushima, wow Matsushima, oh Matsushima,' is a fabrication concocted by people of latter-day.
The legend that Basho composed the haiku that reads, 'Oh Matsushima, wow Matsushima, oh Matsushima,' is a fabrication concocted by modern people.
The legend that Basho composed the haiku that reads, 'Matsushima, Ah! Matsushima! Matsushima,' is a fabrication concocted by modern people.
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。5292_松尾芭蕉のファイルより「松島や～」の意味英訳を訂正しました、

sen.j: 5月13日 藤原3代の跡を尋ねて：
sen.e: June 29, 1689, visited the ruins of the three generations of the FUJIWARA:
June 29, 1689, visited the ruins of the three generations of the FUJIWARA:
June 29, 1689, visited the ruins of the three generations of the Fujiwara:

sen.j: 「三代の栄耀一睡のうちにして、大門の跡は一里こなたにあり」
sen.e: The glory of three generations of the Fujiwara passed as if in a dream. Their Great Gate lies in ruins, two miles this side of the castle.'
The glory of three generations of the Fujiwara passed as if in a dream. Their Great Gate lies in ruins, two miles this side of the castle.'
The glory of three generations of the Fujiwara passed as if in a dream. Their Great Gate lies in ruins, two miles this side of the castle.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。余分なスペースを削除しました。

sen.j: 「国破れて山河あり 城春にして草青みたり」という杜甫の詩「春望」を踏まえて詠む。
sen.e: Composed in line with Shunbo, a poem by Toho that reads, 'The country is destroyed; yet mountains and rivers remain and spring comes to the castle; the grass is green again.'
Composed in line with Shunbo, a poem by Toho that reads, 'The country is destroyed; yet mountains and rivers remain and spring comes to the castle; the grass is green again.'
Composed in line with Shunbo, a poem by Toho that reads, 'The country is destroyed; yet mountains and rivers remain and spring comes to the castle; the grass is green again.'
sen.cmt: 全角の’’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 夏草や 兵（つはもの）どもが 夢のあと
sen.e: Mounds of summer grass - the place where noble soldiers one time dreamed a dream
Mounds of summer grass - the place where noble soldiers one time dreamed a dream
Mounds of summer grass - the place where noble soldiers one time dreamed a dream

sen.j: 五月雨の 降り残してや 光堂
sen.e: So the rains of spring fall and fall, yet leave untouched this bright Hall of God
So the rains of spring fall and fall, yet leave untouched this bright Hall of God
So the rains of spring fall and fall, yet leave untouched this bright Hall of God

sen.j: 5月27日 立石寺（山形市山寺）にて。
sen.e: July 13, 1689, composed at Risshaku-ji Temple (Yama-dera Temple, Yamagata City).
July 13, 1689, composed at Risshaku-ji Temple (Yama-dera Temple, Yamagata City).

sen.j: 閑さや岩にしみ入る蝉の声

The utter silence …. cutting through the very stone a cicada's rasp
The utter silence …, cutting through the very stone a cicada's rasp

sen.j: 5月29日 最上川の河港大石田での発句を改めたもの。
sen.e: July 15, 1689, revised the first line of the haiku composed at the river port of Mogami-gawa River Oishida (Oishida in Yamagata Prefecture).

sen.j: 五月雨を あつめて早し 最上川（もがみがわ）

Gathering the rains of summer, how swift it is - Mogami-gawa River

sen.j: 6月5日 羽黒山にて。
sen.e: July 21, 1689, composed at Haguro-yama Mountain.
July 21, 1689, composed at Haguro-yama Mountain.
July 21, 1689, composed at Haguro-yama Mountain.

sen.j: 涼しさやほの三か月の羽黒山
sen.e: Such lovely coolness … palely now the crescent moon on Mount Haguro
Such lovely coolness … palely now the crescent moon on Mount Haguro
Such lovely coolness … palely now the crescent moon on Mount Haguro

sen.j: 6月6日 月山にて。
sen.e: July 22, 1689, composed at Gassan Mountain.
July 22, 1689, composed at Gassan Mountain.
July 22, 1689, composed at Gassan Mountain.

sen.j: 雲の峰いくつ崩れて月の山
sen.e: How many cloud peaks have come tumbling down upon the moon's own mountain

sen.j: 6月7日 湯殿山にて。
sen.e: July 23, 1689, composed at Yudono-san Mountain.
July 23, 1689, composed at Yudono-san Mountain.
July 23, 1689, composed at Yudono-san Mountain.

sen.j: 語られぬ湯殿にぬらす袂（たもと）かな
sen.e: I cannot speak of Mount Yudono – yet see how west my sleeve is now
I cannot speak of Mount Yudono – yet see how west my sleeve is now

sen.j: 6月10日 鶴岡にて。
sen.e: July 26, 1689, composed in Tsuruoka.
July 26, 1689, composed in Tsuruoka.
July 26, 1689, composed in Tsuruoka.

sen.j: 珍しや山をいで羽の初茄子び
sen.e: Arrived in Dewa Province after traveling in the mountains for days, how lovely the color of early eggplants.
Arrived in Dewa Province after traveling in the mountains for days, how lovely the color of early eggplants.
Arrived in Dewa Province after traveling in the mountains for days, how lovely the color of early eggplants.

sen.j: 6月14日 酒田にて。
sen.e: July 30, 1689, composed in Sakata.
July 30, 1689, composed in Sakata.
July 30, 1689, composed in Sakata.

sen.j: 暑き日を海にいれたり最上川
sen.e: The blistering sun is gathered in the sea by Mogami-gawa River
The blistering sun is gathered in the sea by Mogami-gawa River
The blistering sun is gathered in the sea by Mogami-gawa River

sen.j: あつみ山や吹浦かけて夕すヾみ
sen.e: From Atsumi-yama Mountain all the way to Windy Bay - the cool of evening
From Atsumi-yama Mountain all the way to Windy Bay - the cool of evening
From Atsumi-yama Mountain all the way to Windy Bay - the cool of evening

sen.j: 6月16日 象潟（きさがた）は松島と並ぶ風光明媚な歌枕として名高かった。
sen.e: August 1, 1689, arrived in Kisagata which was well known as a utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) for its superb views taking a place beside Matsushima.
August 1, 1689, arrived in Kisagata which was well known as an utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) for its superb views taking a place beside Matsushima.
August 1, 1689, arrived in Kisagata which was well known as an utamakura (a place famed in classical Japanese poetry) for its superb views taking a place beside Matsushima.

sen.j: 象潟を芭蕉は「俤（おもかげ）松島に通ひて、また異なり。
sen.e: On Kisagata, 'It reminded me of Matsushima but there was a difference.
On Kisagata, 'It reminded me of Matsushima but there was a difference.
On Kisagata, 'It reminded me of Matsushima but there was a difference.
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 松島は笑ふが如く、象潟は憾む（うらむ）が如し。
sen.e: Whereas Matsushima seemed to smile, Kisagata had a gloomy, bitter air.
Whereas Matsushima seemed to smile, Kisagata had a gloomy, bitter air.
Whereas Matsushima seemed to smile, Kisagata had a gloomy, bitter air.

sen.j: 寂しさに悲しみを加へて、地勢 魂を悩ますに似たり。」と形容した。
sen.e: The lonely, melancholy scene evoked a troubled human soul,' described Basho.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: The lonely, melancholy scene evoked a troubled human soul,' described Basho.
The lonely, melancholy scene evoked a troubled human soul,' described Basho.
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 象潟や 雨に西施（せいし）が ねぶの花
sen.e: Kisagata rain - Seishi lying asleep with wet mimosa flowers
Kisagata rain - Seishi lying asleep with wet mimosa flowers
Kisagata rain - Seishi lying asleep with wet mimosa flowers

sen.j: 西施は中国春秋時代の美女の名。
sen.e: Seishi is the name of a beautiful woman in the Chunqiu period in China.
Seishi is the name of a beautiful woman in the Chunqiu period in China.
Seishi is the name of a beautiful woman in the Chunqiu period in China.

sen.j: 汐越（しおこし）や鶴はぎぬれて海涼し
sen.e: Crossing of the tides … a crane, its long legs splashing - ah how cool the sea
Crossing of the tides … a crane, its long legs splashing - ah how cool the sea
Crossing of the tides … a crane, its long legs splashing - ah how cool the sea

sen.j: 7月4日 出雲崎（いずもざき）での句。
sen.e: August 18, 1689, composed in Izumozaki
August 18, 1689, composed in Izumozaki
August 18, 1689, composed in Izumozaki

sen.j: 荒海や 佐渡によこたふ 天の河
sen.e: Billow-crested seas! Flowing towards Sado Isle heaven's Milky Way
Billow-crested seas! Flowing towards Sado Isle heaven's Milky Way
Billow-crested seas! Flowing towards Sado Isle heaven's Milky Way

tit.e: Ichiburi no seki (the barrier station of Ichiburi)
Ichiburi no seki (the barrier station of Ichiburi)
Ichiburi no seki (the barrier station of Ichiburi)

sen.j: 7月13日 親不知（おやしらず）の難所を越えて市振（いちぶり）の宿に泊まる。
sen.e: August 27, 1689, having cleared the grueling path along Oyashirazu (Oyashirazu beach in Niigata Prefecture), Basho stayed at an inn in the town of Ichiburi
August 27, 1689, having cleared the grueling path along Oyashirazu (Oyashirazu beach in Niigata Prefecture), Basho stayed at an inn in the town of Ichiburi
August 27, 1689, having cleared the grueling path along Oyashirazu (Oyashirazu beach in Niigata Prefecture), Basho stayed at an inn in the town of Ichiburi

sen.j: 一家（ひとつや）に 遊女もねたり 萩と月
sen.e: Beneath this same roof prostitutes were sleeping too – clover and the moon
Beneath this same roof prostitutes were sleeping too – clover and the moon
Beneath this same roof prostitutes were sleeping too – clover and the moon

sen.j: 7月14日 数しらぬ川を渡り終えて。
sen.e: August 28, 1689, composed after crossing countless rivers.
August 28, 1689, composed after crossing countless rivers.
August 28, 1689, composed after crossing countless rivers.

sen.j: わせの香や 分入（わけいる）右は 有磯海（ありそうみ）
sen.e: Scent of early rice - to the right, as we push through, the Ariso Sea
Scent of early rice - to the right, as we push through, the Ariso Sea
Scent of early rice - to the right, as we push through, the Ariso Sea

sen.j: 7月15日から24日 城下の名士達が幾度も句会を設ける。
sen.e: Between August 29 and September 7, 1689, distinguished people in the castle town held Kukai (haiku meets) on several occasions.
Between August 29 and September 7, 1689, distinguished people in the castle town held Kukai (haiku meets) on several occasions.
Between August 29 and September 7, 1689, distinguished people in the castle town held Kukai (haiku meets) on several occasions.

sen.j: 蕉門の早世を知る。
sen.e: Learned about the untimely death of Shomon (a pupil of Basho).
Learned about the untimely death of Shomon (a pupil of Basho).
Learned about the untimely death of Shomon (a pupil of Basho).

sen.j: 曾良は体調勝れず。
sen.e: Sora was unwell.
Sora was unwell.
Sora was unwell.

sen.j: 塚も動け 我泣聲（わがなくこえ）は 秋の風
sen.e: The gravemound should move! My crying voice is echoed in the autumn wind
The gravemound should move! My crying voice is echoed in the autumn wind
The grave mound should move! My crying voice is echoed in the autumn wind
sen.cmt: スペース補足しました。

sen.j: 秋すゝし 手毎（てごと）にむけや 瓜天茄（うりなすび）
sen.e: The cool of autumn - our hands are busy peeling melon and eggplant
The cool of autumn - our hands are busy peeling melon and eggplant
The cool of autumn - our hands are busy peeling melon and eggplant

sen.j: 当地を後にしつつ途中の吟
sen.e: Leaving this place, composed on the road
Leaving this place, composed on the road
Leaving this place, composed on the road

sen.j: あかあかと 日は難面（つれなく）も あきの風
sen.e: The red, blazing red, of the pitiless sun - yet autumn in the wind
The red, blazing red, of the pitiless sun - yet autumn in the wind
The red, blazing red, of the pitiless sun - yet autumn in the wind

sen.j: 7月25日から27日 山中温泉から戻り8月6日から7日 懇願され滞在長引くも安宅の関記述なし。
sen.e: September 8 to September 10, 1689, returned from Yamanaka-onsen Hot Springs and September 19 and 20, Basho extended his stay at the request of his host but no mention of Ataka no seki (the Ataka barrier station) was made.

September 8 to September 10, 1689, returned from Yamanaka-onsen Hot Springs and September 19 and 20, Basho extended his stay at the request of his host but no mention of Ataka no seki (the Ataka barrier station) was made.

sen.j: しほらしき 名や小松吹 萩すゝき
sen.e: What a lovely name - the wind blows through young pines, bush clover, pampas grass
What a lovely name - the wind blows through young pines, bush clover, pampas grass
What a lovely name - the wind blows through young pines, bush clover, pampas grass

tit.e: Katayamazu (Katayamazu in Ishikawa Prefecture), Kaga Province
Katayamazu (Katayamazu in Ishikawa Prefecture), Kaga Province
Katayamazu (Katayamazu in Ishikawa Prefecture), Kaga Province

sen.j: 7月26日 平家物語（巻第七）や源平盛衰記も伝える篠原の戦い（篠原合戦）、斎藤実盛を偲ぶ。
sen.e: September 9, 1689, commemorated the Battle of Shinohara and Sanemori SAITO mentioned in Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike) (Volume 7) and Genpei Seisuiki (The Rise and Decline of the Minamoto and Taira clans).

September 9, 1689, commemorated the Battle of Shinohara and Sanemori SAITO mentioned in Heike Monogatari (The tale of the Heike) (Volume 7) and Genpei Seisuiki (The Rise and Decline of the Minamoto and Taira clans).

sen.j: 小松にて吟。
sen.e: Composed at Komatsu.
Composed at Komatsu.
Composed at Komatsu.

sen.j: むざんやな 甲の下の きりぎりす
sen.e: The pity of it….trapped underneath a helmet a cricket chirping
The pity of it….trapped underneath a helmet a cricket chirping
The pity of it….trapped underneath a helmet a cricket chirping

sen.j: 7月27日から8月5日 加賀の国山中温泉で大垣を目前に安堵したか八泊する。
sen.e: September 10 to 18, 1689, it seems that Basho was relieved to have come so close to Ogaki, he and Sora stayed at Yamanaka-onsen Hot Springs in Kaga Province for 8 days.
September 10 to 18, 1689, it seems that Basho was relieved to have come so close to Ogaki, he and Sora stayed at Yamanaka-onsen Hot Springs in Kaga Province for 8 days.
September 10 to 18, 1689, it seems that Basho was relieved to have come so close to Ogaki, he and Sora stayed at Yamanaka-onsen Hot Springs in Kaga Province for 8 days.

sen.j: その後、腹を病む曾良を先に帰し二人はここで別れた。
sen.e: Basho subsequently sent Sora who was suffering from stomach trouble home first whereby they went separate ways from this point.
Basho subsequently sent Sora who was suffering from stomach trouble home first whereby they went separate ways from this point.
Basho subsequently sent Sora who was suffering from stomach trouble home first whereby they went separate ways from this point.

sen.j: 和泉屋に宿する。
sen.e: Basho stayed at Izumiya (inn).
Basho stayed at Izumiya (inn).
Basho stayed at Izumiya (inn).

sen.j: 山中や 菊はたおらぬ 湯の匂
sen.e: At Yamanaka, no need for chrysanthemums - the scent of hot springs
At Yamanaka, no need for chrysanthemums - the scent of hot springs
At Yamanaka, no need for chrysanthemums - the scent of hot springs

sen.j: 今日よりや 書付消さん 笠の露
sen.e: From this day the words inside my hat will vanish with the dew of tears
From this day the words inside my hat will vanish with the dew of tears
From this day the words inside my hat will vanish with the dew of tears

sen.j: 行行（ゆきゆき）て たふれ伏（たおれふす）とも 萩の原 曾良
sen.e: Onwards I must go - if I should fall, let it be amidst bush clover
Onwards I must go - if I should fall, let it be amidst bush clover
Onwards I must go - if I should fall, let it be amidst bush clover' by Sora
sen.cmt: by Sora補足しました。' '補足しました。

sen.j: 8月5日 小松へ戻る道中参詣、奇岩遊仙境を臨み。
sen.e: September 18, 1689, on the way back to Komatsu, composed while viewing rocks of unusual shape in the area.
September 18, 1689, on the way back to Komatsu, composed while viewing rocks of unusual shape in the area.
September 18, 1689, on the way back to Komatsu, composed while viewing rocks of unusual shape in the area.

sen.j: 石山の 石より白し 秋の風
sen.e: Whiter far than all the stones of Ishiyama - the autumnal wind
Whiter far than all the stones of Ishiyama - the autumnal wind
Whiter far than all the stones of Ishiyama - the autumnal wind

tit.j: 大聖寺 熊谷山全昌寺
tit.e: Daisho-ji Temple and Zensho-ji Temple, Kumagaya-yama Mountain
Daisho-ji Temple and Zensho-ji Temple, Kumagaya-yama Mountain
Daisho-ji Temple and Zensho-ji Temple, Kumagaya-yama Mountain

sen.j: 8月7日 前夜曾良も泊まる。
sen.e: September 20, 1689, Sora also stayed at the family temple of Izumiya overnight.
September 20, 1689, Sora also stayed at the family temple of Izumiya overnight.
September 20, 1689, Sora also stayed at the family temple of Izumiya overnight.

sen.j: 和泉屋の菩提寺、一宿の礼、庭掃き。
sen.e: Basho swept the yard of the family temple of Izumiya as a token of gratitude for their hospitality.
Basho swept the yard of the family temple of Izumiya as a token of gratitude for their hospitality.
Basho swept the yard of the family temple of Izumiya as a token of gratitude for their hospitality.

sen.j: 庭掃（にわはき）て 出（いで）ばや寺に 散柳（ちるやなぎ）
sen.e: Let's sweep the garden then leave – in the temple the willow leaves fall
Let's sweep the garden then leave – in the temple the willow leaves fall
Let's sweep the garden then leave – in the temple the willow leaves fall

sen.j: 終宵（よもすがら） 秋風聞や うらの山 曾良
sen.e: Throughout the long night, listening to the autumn wind in the hills behind
Throughout the long night, listening to the autumn wind in the hills behind
Throughout the long night, listening to the autumn wind in the hills behind

tit.j: 福井あわら市 吉崎

sen.j: 8月9日 西行の一首にて数景尽たりと吟せず。
sen.e: September 22, 1689, Basho did not compose any poem saying that in his single poem, Saigyo crystallized the essence of the scene of this place.
September 22, 1689, Basho did not compose any poem saying that in his single poem, Saigyo crystallized the essence of the scene of this place.
September 22, 1689, Basho did not compose any poem saying that in his single poem, Saigyo crystallized the essence of the scene of this place.

sen.j: 蓮如ゆかり吉崎御坊の地。
sen.e: Composed (by Saigyo) in the locality of Yoshizaki Gobo associated with Rennyo.
Composed (by Saigyo) in the locality of Yoshizaki Gobo associated with Rennyo.
Composed (by Saigyo) in the locality of Yoshizaki Gobo associated with Rennyo.

sen.j: 夜もすがら あらしに波を 運ばせて 月を垂れたる 汐越の松 西行
sen.e: Throughout the long night, the waves are lashed by a storm, that drives them to shore - and moonlight drips from their boughs, the pines of Shiogoshi' by Saigyo
Throughout the long night, the waves are lashed by a storm, that drives them to shore - and moonlight drips from their boughs, the pines of Shiogoshi' by Saigyo
Throughout the long night, the waves are lashed by a storm, that drives them to shore - and moonlight drips from their boughs, the pines of Shiogoshi' by Saigyo

sen.j: 8月14日頃、敦賀に到着。
sen.e: Around September 27, 1689, arrived in Tsuruga.
Around September 27, 1689, arrived in Tsuruga.
Around September 27, 1689, arrived in Tsuruga.

sen.j: 北国の日和あいにくで名月見れず。
sen.e: Unfortunately, with the weather of the northland being uncooperative, Basho was unable to view the full moon.
Unfortunately, with the weather of the northland being uncooperative, Basho was unable to view the full moon.
Unfortunately, with the weather of the northland being uncooperative, Basho was unable to view the full moon.

sen.j: ふるき名の 角鹿（つぬが）や恋し 秋の月
sen.e: Beach of Tsuruga in the beautiful autumn moonlight has the atmosphere of a surreal tale, compelling me to call it by its old name Tsunuga.
Beach of Tsuruga in the beautiful autumn moonlight has the atmosphere of a surreal tale, compelling me to call it by its old name Tsunuga.
Beach of Tsuruga in the beautiful autumn moonlight has the atmosphere of a surreal tale, compelling me to call it by its old name Tsunuga.

sen.j: 月清し 遊行（ゆうぎょう）が持てる 砂の上
sen.e: Pure light of the moon glistering on the grains of sand brought by the pilgrims
Pure light of the moon glistering on the grains of sand brought by the pilgrims
Pure light of the moon glistering on the grains of sand brought by the pilgrims

sen.j: 名月や 北国日和（ほっこびより） 定（さだめ）なき
sen.e: Night of the full moon – the weather in the north land so often changes
Night of the full moon – the weather in the north land so often changes
Night of the full moon – the weather in the north land so often changes

sen.j: 8月21日頃、大垣に到着。
sen.e: Around October 4, 1689, arrived in Ogaki.
Around October 4, 1689, arrived in Ogaki.
Around October 4, 1689, arrived in Ogaki.

sen.j: 門人たちが集い労わる。
sen.e: Basho's pupils gathered in appreciation for his long arduous journey.
Basho's pupils gathered in appreciation for his long arduous journey.
Basho's pupils gathered in appreciation for his long arduous journey.
sen.cmt: 全角の’を半角にしました。

sen.j: 9月6日 芭蕉は「伊勢の遷宮をおがまんと、また船に乗り」出発する。
sen.e: October 18, 1689, Basho set out to view Ise no sengu (the temporary removal of the object of worship from The Grand Shrine of Ise) by a boat.
October 18, 1689, Basho set out to view Ise no sengu (the temporary removal of the object of worship from The Grand Shrine of Ise) by a boat.
October 18, 1689, Basho set out to view Ise no sengu (the temporary removal of the object of worship from The Grand Shrine of Ise) by a boat.

sen.j: 結びの句
sen.e: Basho composed the concluding haiku of this travelogue.
Basho composed the concluding haiku of this travelogue.
Basho composed the concluding haiku of this travelogue.

sen.j: 蛤（はまぐり）の ふたみにわかれ行く 秋ぞ
sen.e: Like a clam ripped from its shell, autumn is deepening now
Like a clam ripped from its shell, autumn is deepening now
